anssih:
Here is an English version of the official numbering plan referenced above:
https://www.viestintavirasto.fi/attachments/maaraykset/Regulation_32.pdf
. Page 19: 020* and 029* are nationwide service/subscriber numbers
Page 20: 030* and 039* are nationwide service/subscriber numbers
Page 21: Some 060* ranges are nationwide service numbers, rest of 060* and 069* reserved
Page 24: 0800* are nationwide toll-free numbers, rest of 080* and 089* reserved.
Section 6, paragraph 3, on page 3 clarifies that "nationwide" numbers are non-geographic.
The document apparently uses slightly different nomenclature - I used "national" in the commit where the document says "nationwide", while the document uses "national" to mean any domestic number...

. (a) MetadataSource and all 2 of its implementations (1, 2) are non-public so even when we say public PhoneNumberUtil.createInstance(MetadataSource) public usage cannot pass anything to this method. FWIW I put this in the pending changes too.
(b) Clients can call getInstance(), which under the hood will (the first time) do the same as calling createInstance(new MultiFileMetadataSourceImpl(DEFAULT_METADATA_LOADER)) - (any time after that it will use the already created instance). The alternative would be to use their own loader, which they can do via createInstance(MetadataLoader), or to specify SingleFileMetadataSourceImpl, which they programmatically cannot do, and which we don't support anyway (no jars with single file right now).
. To clarify that last point, the second "alternative" is actually not possible right now, even with this method signature staying public. I'm not saying it wouldn't be good to have it public, or that it's not useful for clients, but it's not usable so the signature shouldn't say public.

. LGTM. LGTM. Since the GB data is now generated from a new internal representation, the mapping files are no longer editable directly, they are purely automatically generated. As such we can no longer accept any pull requests for these files.
The good news is that we should be able to easily merge any new carrier data into our data and regenerate new, consistent/minimal versions of the mapping files. The only time a mapping would not appear in our generated files is if the prefix was not one we considered a valid range (but since your source looks to be good, that would indicate that we might have missing ranges, which could then be added).
The best thing to do is provide us with your original data for carrier mappings (e.g. Offcom data) in a machine readable way, which we can then process and merge into our base data to regenerate correct mapping files. We can handle merging mapping files in the "prefix|carrier name" format, so that shouldn't be an issue. It looks like the data you have fits this bill.
This also means we should no longer show these files as being directly generated from your project (since they aren't anymore) but we're happy to continue to credit you for the source of the data (i.e. we should make a small adjustment to the comment at the top of this file).
Also, just to explain, the mapping files we generate are always minimal now, so:
4477442|Core Communication
4477443|Core Communication
4477444|Core Communication
4477445|Core Communication
4477446|Core Communication
4477447|Core Communication
4477448|Core Communication
4477449|Core Communication
would never exist in our data, only:
447744|Core Communication
(or perhaps even a shorter prefix). This shortening can only be done with access to all the range data, so as not to "over shorten" ranges. This is fine, since it returns exactly the same result for all valid numbers, but means that you will now always have a diff between the "unshortened" mappings from someone like Offcom and the mappings we generate.
Funnily enough I was just about to send out an announcement email explaining some of this to potential contributors, since I didn't want anyone spending time working on exact patches we can no longer accept (we still gladly accept data sources, just not pull requests to modify data files directly).. Since the GB data is now generated from a new internal representation, the mapping files are no longer editable directly, they are purely automatically generated. As such we can no longer accept any pull requests for these files.
The good news is that we should be able to easily merge any new carrier data into our data and regenerate new, consistent/minimal versions of the mapping files. The only time a mapping would not appear in our generated files is if the prefix was not one we considered a valid range (but since your source looks to be good, that would indicate that we might have missing ranges, which could then be added).
The best thing to do is provide us with your original data for carrier mappings (e.g. Offcom data) in a machine readable way, which we can then process and merge into our base data to regenerate correct mapping files. We can handle merging mapping files in the "prefix|carrier name" format, so that shouldn't be an issue. It looks like the data you have fits this bill.
This also means we should no longer show these files as being directly generated from your project (since they aren't anymore) but we're happy to continue to credit you for the source of the data (i.e. we should make a small adjustment to the comment at the top of this file).
Also, just to explain, the mapping files we generate are always minimal now, so:
4477442|Core Communication
4477443|Core Communication
4477444|Core Communication
4477445|Core Communication
4477446|Core Communication
4477447|Core Communication
4477448|Core Communication
4477449|Core Communication
would never exist in our data, only:
447744|Core Communication
(or perhaps even a shorter prefix). This shortening can only be done with access to all the range data, so as not to "over shorten" ranges. This is fine, since it returns exactly the same result for all valid numbers, but means that you will now always have a diff between the "unshortened" mappings from someone like Offcom and the mappings we generate.
Funnily enough I was just about to send out an announcement email explaining some of this to potential contributors, since I didn't want anyone spending time working on exact patches we can no longer accept (we still gladly accept data sources, just not pull requests to modify data files directly).. > The data in the merge request is compressed as far as it can safely go based on the current Ofcom allocations.
But the semantics of our mapping file allow for more "compression".

In your example of Core Communications, the shortened 447744 shouldn't be used, as Core Communications have only been allocated 2-9 (not 0 or 1).

That's fine. The carrier mapping in our library was never meant to mean "if it has this prefix it's valid".
It means "if it's valid and it has this prefix, then here's the carrier name". The 0/1 ranges just aren't valid so we don't care what we return for them. If they were allocated then the mapping will be updated to work correctly.
It also relies on inheriting default values from shorter prefixes, so you can have:
123|Foo
1234|Bar
which means "everything that's valid and starts with 123, except 1234, is Foo"
You can trust that it's correct (it just might not have the semantics you thought it did).

As far as the apostrophe is concerned, we follow the convention used in Google Maps of inserting an apostrophe to break up a pair of adjacent vowels (i.e., to show two distinct vowels as opposed to a diphthong). Thus, we write "Xi'an" rather than "Xian" (like http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xi'an). Similarly, we use ü rather than v for Lüliang (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lüliang). For names which are not Chinese in origin, we use (the Latinised form of) the original name, like "Lhasa", since in most cases this is much more recognisable to English speakers. For 大兴安岭地区, libaddressinput has "Da Hinggan Ling Diqu", so you probably are dropping everything after a space if you're just getting "Da": http://i18napis.appspot.com/address/data/CN/黑龙江省/大兴安岭地区 . Hey @keghani,
I am afraid it doesn't solve the issue. While adding OSGI manifest information makes it easier for general class loading it doesn't solve the issue of file loading between artifacts.
In this specific case the PhoneNumberOfflineGeocoder from the "geocoder" JAR is using the PrefixFileReader from the "prefixmapper" JAR to load a file from the "/com/google/i18n/phonenumbers/geocoding/data/" directory in the "geocoder" JAR.
But since PrefixFileReader is using PrefixFileReader.class.getResourceAsStream() to load the files it is using the classloader for the "prefixmapper" JAR and that can't find the files from the "geocoder" JAR classloader.. Hey @keghani,
I am afraid it doesn't solve the issue. While adding OSGI manifest information makes it easier for general class loading it doesn't solve the issue of file loading between artifacts.

But since PrefixFileReader is using PrefixFileReader.class.getResourceAsStream() to load the files it is using the classloader for the "prefixmapper" JAR and that can't find the files from the "geocoder" JAR classloader..

lararennie:
Superseded by https://github.com/googlei18n/libphonenumber/pull/1459. @vbauer:
For the specific use-cases that you mention:
1) Get all country codes (CountryCodeToRegionCodeMap.getCountryCodeToRegionCodeMap().keySet() -- what do you use this for? We could theoretically provide a method e.g. getValidCountryCallingCodes() to return a set of all the valid ones if there's a need for this? This would include global network calling codes e.g. +800 -> would you want that or not?
2) Get region codes by country code (I think we can do it via PhoneNumberUtils#getRegionCodesForCountryCode, so it would be ok, but we can minimize memory usage a little bit, if we use CountryCodeToRegionCodeMap directly without PhoneNumberUtils). -- Do you do something other than just parse the number? Is that why you need this? Maybe an image of your widget would help here?
3) Retrieve CountryCodeToRegionCodeMap.getCountryCodeToRegionCodeMap() and send this information from server-side to client side (via GWT RPC). It is necessary for our UI components. -- What do you do with this?
Given the current API, what we'd expect users to do is call getSupportedRegions (and optionally getSupportedGlobalNetworkCallingCodes as well), and then use this to build a custom map of the data they want, keyed off whatever they want. (E.g. you could imagine building a map of calling code to a "country" object that contains an image link to a flag and the name(s) of the countries to show on hover). Does this not work for your use-case? I wouldn't think the region-codes themselves are something you want to show to users directly in your UI.

Previously, keghani (Keghani Kouzoujian) wrote…

I just had a chat with @hagbard (Thanks!) Interesting stuff :)
So, we're checking above "if (metadata != null)"; we only proceed with loading if metadata isn't already in the map.
So by the time we get to the last line in this method, if oldValue isn't null then we had at least 2 threads go through the loading, and one thread "won" and their loaded object is in the map. The reasons we return that object rather than the one this thread loaded are:
(1) We want to honor the "load that won"
(2) Idiomatically, we want getMultiFileMetadata to return the same object to anyone who passes in the same key and map, not just "objects that are equal"; and indeed, an object that's in the map
(3) We want the object/s that didn't get into the map to be promptly garbage collected.
FWIW: What I said earlier about possibly returning to the thread early due to the return value already being computed does not apply here, but might with double locking IUUC. Anyway, that was just me speculating (I failed the interview!)

- Changed tag to vX.Y.Z from libphonenumber-X.Y.Z; this may affect ports and
  derived projects.
  +Metadata structure changes:
  - - Mobile and Fixed-Line blocks are no longer assumed to inherit missing data
  -   from the GeneralDesc, but are treated like every other phone number type.
  -   This means that for the non-geographical country codes, like +800, the
  -   example number has been moved from generalDesc to the relevant number types,
  -   and the code in getExampleNumberForNonGeoEntity has been changed to look at
  -   these sub-types for an example number.
  -   This also means that the "NA" and "-1" blocks present in the metadata to
  -   indicate that no mobile or fixed-line numbers appear for the entity have been
  -   removed.
  -   There should no longer be an exampleNumber at the generalDesc level, but it
  -   should be present at every PhoneNumberDesc with data.
    +Metadata changes

- to format, you need a PhoneNumber object
- to get one, you must parse some text calling "parse"
- if you do this with an invalid country calling code, we will throw an exception.
Sounds like you aren't calling parse, in which case you are highly likely to be corrupting data, e.g. for Italian fixed-line numbers.
The only case where I could see this method being useful is for formerly valid country calling codes that no longer are, but in that case I would call isPossibleNumberWithReason on the number instead anyway since it'll tell you if the number seems plausible and if not why not. If the number is way too long or short, formatting it won't give you a very sensible output either....
In any case, you can just call  getRegionCodeForCountryCode and if it is ZZ (unknown), you know it's not a valid one.
Other alternatives: you can also getSupportedRegions and get the country calling code for each one and build the list yourself. Then you can also decide whether you want to include non-geographical entities too like international freephone, with getSupportedGlobalNetworkCallingCodes() which will return those.. - to format, you need a PhoneNumber object
- to get one, you must parse some text calling "parse"
- if you do this with an invalid country calling code, we will throw an exception.
Sounds like you aren't calling parse, in which case you are highly likely to be corrupting data, e.g. for Italian fixed-line numbers.
The only case where I could see this method being useful is for formerly valid country calling codes that no longer are, but in that case I would call isPossibleNumberWithReason on the number instead anyway since it'll tell you if the number seems plausible and if not why not. If the number is way too long or short, formatting it won't give you a very sensible output either....
In any case, you can just call  getRegionCodeForCountryCode and if it is ZZ (unknown), you know it's not a valid one.
Other alternatives: you can also getSupportedRegions and get the country calling code for each one and build the list yourself. . @jias0001 regarding throwing errors, unfortunately it still lacks throwing proper errors on multiple places (see example). I'll see if I can contribute patches to make it more consistent though.
Your explanation makes sense but I think there is a real demand for a proper way to use this library on node.js. If this is something that can be done directly from javascript version, then I'm all for having it on a wiki or any other place of documentation. However, sourcing the closure library on node.js is not just a require away. Because of this, I consider this "wrapper" to actually be a port for node.js, even if they share the same language.
I would certainly prefer if this package could be officially distributed via npm without resorting to any modifications but, until then, I think the community will continue to search for a version that they can simply do require('libphonenumber') and it just works like every other node module.

. > The 0/1 ranges just aren't valid so we don't care what we return for them.

They validate as valid numbers though: http://libphonenumber.appspot.com/phonenumberparser?number=%2B447744012345.
This would be fine, but would require the metadata to be much more accurate than it is now (actual allocated numbers instead of possibly allocated numbers).
According to Ofcom they try to publish data every Wednesday. Carrier Updates certainly aren't that important to be updated so frequently, but if the metadata is being mixed with the compression mentioned above, then that's sure to cause problems.
Keeping with this same number range as an example 77440 is currently not allocated, and currently does not report a carrier. It does however validate as a valid number. If the carrier data was compressed to just '7744': Carrier, and another CP was allocated 77440, then incorrect carrier information would start being shown.

As there is no additional value for keeping these overloading APIs, we have chosen to change the signature of existing APIs itself and it will not break any client code.

It's an advertsing technique for them that anouncing 998 from first step. We should look at reallities, not advertisings. One of important reallities is ITU document that showing 99810 and onother one is registeration system in their offiicial website that registering for 99810 number for now.

Armagetron:
I signed it!. I attached a build log I get when I compile the current version (master HEAD) on a Raspberry Pi with Raspbian Jessie and a gcc 4.9.2. With the fix I provided the error is gone.
I think this is caused by the protobuf compiler which generates C++11 code by default.
. I tested the current libphonenumber (1f69a99ce31df7b7f6c869bfd51dc5d63e96ccc5) together with the current protobuf (google/protobuf@f0a5c1033a7a46b1405a1ce8526d4d9aa6d38375) version with the gcc 4.9 I don't get any errors. So it works without c++11 again.
However if the protobuf team decides to move their future development to a c++11 based version, libphonenumber should probably go the same way so that the newest version can be used. A pre c++11 fork would only receive bug-fix support and on systems that ship the new version by default one would have to manage two versions..
tadfisher:
In a third-party wrapper, it would be much better to depend directly on a Maven artifact rather than repackaging the jar.

Consumers may freely replace the wrapper with the metadata-included dependency in unit tests or cross-platform build variants.
Consumers may freely override the transitive dependency with a later version, not having to wait for the wrapper to catch up.
Having a metadata-less base artifact reduces parallel work if someone wanted to change the metadata-loading facility for another use case, for example loading the rules from a database or the network.

Yes, that still means copying the metadata from the main artifact when building the wrapper, but that is a compile-only dependency for the wrapper, not a runtime dependency for the consumer.. yinzara:
I used the  wrong user to submit the commit. Need to recreate.. I've requested to join but do not have the ability to post.
The issue is not with the overloading of the methods.  The issue is with compatibility of the library with code compiled against older versions.
In my specific example, I have a production application that uses the libphonenumber library running 8.6.0 and uses the 'parse' method of PhoneNumberUtil.  I get a report that we are rejecting a specific phone number as invalid. I see that the change that would make that number valid is in libphonenumber 8.8.2 metadata.   I replace my libphonenumber-8.6.0.jar with libphonenumber-8.8.2.jar.  I restart my application and it crashes because when it attempts to call the original "parse" method of PhoneNumberUtil because the method does not exist (as it was compiled against the prior version which took in a String and the new version takes in a CharSequence).
I am in a regulated environment where recompiling my application will require approval from a regulatory board and cost my company time and resources (and means a delay of at least a month).  I do not need approval when changing public versions of libraries.  Because of this, I have no option but to keep the original 8.6.0 version of the library or recompile my application and go through regulatory approval again.
Because the method signatures changed (even though they changed to an interface that the concrete class implements), code compiled against the original methods will be unable to upgrade to a version of the library without recompiling their library against the newer APIs.
This discourages users of the library from upgrading from prior version of the library as it requires them to recompile their applications and not be backwardly compatible.. I've put together an example to demonstrate my point.
See:
https://github.com/yinzara/libphonenumber-exp
If you run "./compile.sh" that will compile Example.java using libphonenumber-8.6.0.jar
You can then "./run-old.sh 7025251231" and see it correctly validates the number using libphonenumber-8.6.0.jar.
You can then "./run-new.sh 7025251231" and see it throws a NoSuchMethodException because the 'parse' method that takes a String no longer exists.
This means anyone upgrading from libphonenumber-8.6.0 and lower to libphonenumber-8.7.0 and higher will need to recompile their applications first (and some may not even have the original source code).
My pull request will make the library compatible without requiring dependent libraries to recompile.. While I understand your perspective, "good practice" is exactly that, a suggested practice.  
With a library as widely used as libphonenumber, the authors should strive to be backwards and forwards compatible with all changes so that people using the library have the greatest flexibility especially when most changes to the library are metadata about the validity and structure of phone numbers (which implies the library needs to be regularly updated to keep up to date with current metadata).  This a central tenant of the java programming language (i.e. version compatibility).
Many times the library that compiled against libphonenumber is one that the user has no control of (i.e. another third party library that uses libphonenumber in which you utilize that library).   The change made in 8.7.0 is a "breaking change" that causes all prior versions of the library to be incompatible with future versions.   My pull request adds less than 1k to the size of the library and allows for the library to be backward and forward compatible with prior and future versions.
There are already a number of issues filed in different issue trackers on the web in which this problem has occurred outside of my use case:
https://github.com/fbsamples/account-kit-samples-for-android/issues/16
https://github.com/robolectric/robolectric/issues/3320 
I would like a consensus by the community as to reject or accept this patch beyond a single contributor.
I have created a forum post requesting more discussion on the matter.
. I have added an additional example in the above Git repo:
https://github.com/yinzara/libphonenumber-exp
In this example "awesome-shared-library" is an hypothetical shared java library controlled by another organization (whether it be another company not providing you the source or an open source project you do not control).   It depends on libphonenumber-8.6.0.  It uses libphonenumber to validate numbers passed to it before providing it's "awesome" functionality to the user of the library.
"my-app" is a very simple example java library with only a test case in which it depends on libphonenumber-8.8.12 (because it needs the updated metadata because of a change in some phone number regions) and calls a hypothetical "doAwesome" method with an example phone number.
The test case fails because of a runtime MethodNotFoundException.  It it uncorrectable unless the person who provides the "awesome-shared-library" is willing (and still available) to update the library to the newer version and provide an updated compilation.
With this pull request, this issue could have been completely avoided and the library be fully forward and backward compatible.
.

myrkraverk:
According to an old news article (in Icelandic) the transition begun in one region before the others (I can't verify this anymore) so applying automated updates to entire databases is not a good idea; at least not during the transition period.  It also means if you're looking for a record by phone number, you have to consider both prefixes.
If you are writing an auto dialing tool for, say helpdesk operators, you have to be aware of which region is available through the new seven digit number, or the old regional code, or both.
. The old system had regional prefixes.  The new system has seven digit phone numbers and no regional codes.  So during the transition, a Reykjavik phone number could be dialed with nnnnn and 55nnnnn inside the region; and 91-nnnnn and 55nnnnn from outside.

frett:
Based on my understanding of OSGi, these directives only have an impact on how Classes are exposed in an OSGi environment. Since there are only resources within the data directory this statement would actually have no impact on the generated meta-data. I'm going to remove it since it has no actual effect.
. I hadn't tested out the geocoder module, I just took the rules that were defined in the previous patch and included them.
Unfortunately, I believe PhoneNumberToTimeZonesMapper being in the same package as all of libphonenumber will cause wiring issues within an OSGi environment if it's exported.
Within an OSGi environment each jar/bundle gets it's own ClassLoader. For external imports the environment links these ClassLoaders together based on the Export-Package meta-data. The environment chooses a single ClassLoader per imported package (not class) to link. This would mean that exporting com.google.i18n.phonenumbers within the geocoder jar would cause a conflict with the main libphonenumber jar.
